contents.title: A fieldguide for independent strategy consultants
contents.generated_title: A fieldguide for independent strategy consultants
contents.description_html: I've been enjoying writing posts recently that are more collections of half-formed thoughts than complete works and so I'm going to do it again with this post. What follows is an outline, or a collection of conversation starters, for digital strategy consulting.
contents.description: I've been enjoying writing posts recently that are more collections of half-formed thoughts than complete works and so I'm going to do it again with this post. What follows is an outline, or a collection of conversation starters, for digital strategy consulting.

source.title: A fieldguide for independent strategy consultants

contents.title: The Consultant's Grain
contents.description_html: Why (their) culture eats (your) strategy for breakfast You might think that being a consultant is easy. Clients hire you to help change their company in some way. You make some recommendations and provide some insights and then... The change rarely happens like you recommended. Why is that?
contents.description: Why (their) culture eats (your) strategy for breakfast You might think that being a consultant is easy. Clients hire you to help change their company in some way. You make some recommendations and provide some insights and then... The change rarely happens like you recommended. Why is that?

contents.title: Strategy is the organic flow of ideas and people
contents.generated_title: Strategy is the organic flow of ideas and people
contents.description_html: I'm currently reading the wonderful book Seeking like a state about how top-down ideas for change inspired by high modernism often fail because they don't accurately reflect the organic nature of networks and people. I can't help but feel that most top-down strategy fails for the same reason.
contents.description: I'm currently reading the wonderful book Seeking like a state about how top-down ideas for change inspired by high modernism often fail because they don't accurately reflect the organic nature of networks and people. I can't help but feel that most top-down strategy fails for the same reason.

source.title: Strategy is the organic flow of ideas and people

contents.title: Atemporality of the Corporation
contents.description_html: How does an organization "think" about the future? On what time horizon do imagined company futures appear? How long does corporate history remain in the "memory" of the organization? Corporate history is fascinating to me. Despite the constant non-stop creation of documentation (emails, documents, meetings notes, slack messages) - the history of a company is largely (if not entirely) oral.
contents.description: How does an organization "think" about the future? On what time horizon do imagined company futures appear? How long does corporate history remain in the "memory" of the organization? Corporate history is fascinating to me. Despite the constant non-stop creation of documentation (emails, documents, meetings notes, slack messages) - the history of a company is largely (if not entirely) oral.

contents.title: How to get things done
contents.description_html: Two interesting frameworks for trying to get things done within an organization
contents.description: Two interesting frameworks for trying to get things done within an organization

contents.title: Strategy and stewardship
contents.description_html: The problem with strategy work is that it's often a sprint. A short burst of work, done periodically to set the vision and the strategy. If you enjoy strategy work, are you doomed to chase short term strategy sprints? And, by the way, who's ensuring that the execution of the strategy is in line with the vision?
contents.description: The problem with strategy work is that it's often a sprint. A short burst of work, done periodically to set the vision and the strategy. If you enjoy strategy work, are you doomed to chase short term strategy sprints? And, by the way, who's ensuring that the execution of the strategy is in line with the vision?

contents.title: High Fidelity Consulting
contents.description_html: This little book Legible Practices from Helsinki Design Lab continues to deliver gems of wisdom: Ideas without details and details without ideas are both risky, so IDEO relied on high-resolution provocations that combined both. Ah. There's a rich vein of wisdom tightly bound around that phrase.
contents.description: This little book Legible Practices from Helsinki Design Lab continues to deliver gems of wisdom: Ideas without details and details without ideas are both risky, so IDEO relied on high-resolution provocations that combined both. Ah. There's a rich vein of wisdom tightly bound around that phrase.

contents.title: The power of labels
contents.description_html: One of the greatest emotions that comes with being self-employed is being free. Free to choose work, clients, hours, location. Freedom to be your own boss. Freedom to make decisions. But this freedom comes with a very closely-felt sense of being un-tethered. Of being adrift at sea with the fathomless ocean below and no coast in sight.
contents.description: One of the greatest emotions that comes with being self-employed is being free. Free to choose work, clients, hours, location. Freedom to be your own boss. Freedom to make decisions. But this freedom comes with a very closely-felt sense of being un-tethered. Of being adrift at sea with the fathomless ocean below and no coast in sight.

contents.title: Ways of Seeing
contents.description_html: How to recognize and understand culture inside a client's organization "One thing about which fish know exactly nothing is water, since they have no anti-environment which would enable them to perceive the element they live in."
contents.description: How to recognize and understand culture inside a client's organization "One thing about which fish know exactly nothing is water, since they have no anti-environment which would enable them to perceive the element they live in."

contents.title: I, consultant?
contents.description_html: The struggle to define who you are as an independent and the promise of charging more for your work Thanks to Toby Shorin of Co-authored by Tom Critchlow & Toby Shorin Subpixel Space for helping put this piece together. Toby's comments are marked in purple throughout the piece.
contents.description: The struggle to define who you are as an independent and the promise of charging more for your work Thanks to Toby Shorin of Co-authored by Tom Critchlow & Toby Shorin Subpixel Space for helping put this piece together. Toby's comments are marked in purple throughout the piece.

contents.title: Strange Attraction
contents.description_html: How to generate leads for an independent consulting practice The Lorenz Attractor is a chaotic system - a strange attractor. It's an elegant and beautiful mathematical object that looks a bit like this: Chaotic systems are often referenced in popular culture via the well-known butterfly effect: "Does the flap of a butterfly's wings in Brazil set off a tornado in Texas?".
contents.description: How to generate leads for an independent consulting practice The Lorenz Attractor is a chaotic system - a strange attractor. It's an elegant and beautiful mathematical object that looks a bit like this: Chaotic systems are often referenced in popular culture via the well-known butterfly effect: "Does the flap of a butterfly's wings in Brazil set off a tornado in Texas?".

contents.title: How (and why) to roll your own frameworks in consulting engagements
contents.generated_title: How (and why) to roll your own frameworks in consulting engagements
contents.description_html: And the power of making simple, true frameworks with clients In this post I'm going to argue that bringing pre-existing off-the-shelf models and frameworks to my client work is the biggest mistake I've made in the past two years. A framework as I'm going to refer to it in this post is essentially a useful abstraction.
contents.description: And the power of making simple, true frameworks with clients In this post I'm going to argue that bringing pre-existing off-the-shelf models and frameworks to my client work is the biggest mistake I've made in the past two years. A framework as I'm going to refer to it in this post is essentially a useful abstraction.

source.title: How (and why) to roll your own frameworks in consulting engagements

contents.title: The Strategic Independent
contents.description_html: How to do better work for more money, whether you're a designer, writer or strategist. In this post I want to break down what I mean by "strategic independent" and why, whatever path you're on and expertise you have, you can bring more value for yourself and your clients by thinking strategically.
contents.description: How to do better work for more money, whether you're a designer, writer or strategist. In this post I want to break down what I mean by "strategic independent" and why, whatever path you're on and expertise you have, you can bring more value for yourself and your clients by thinking strategically.

metadata.description: A series of writings for freelancers, consultants and independents who want to do better work for more money. Hopefully will become a book at some point in 2019.
